skill.name: woocommerce-backend-dev
skill.description: Add or modify WooCommerce backend PHP code following project conventions. Use when creating new classes, methods, hooks, or modifying existing backend code. **MUST be invoked before writing any PHP unit tests.**
skill.summary: Add or modify WooCommerce backend PHP code following project conventions. Use when creating new clas...
skill.author: woocommerce

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only markdown documentation with no executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access. It provides purely instructional content for developers writing WooCommerce backend PHP code.

content.value_statement: WooCommerce backend development requires following strict project conventions for classes, hooks, and testing. This skill provides comprehensive guidelines for creating standards-compliant PHP code that integrates properly with the WooCommerce architecture.
actual_capabilities: Create new PHP classes following PSR-4 autoloading and Automattic\WooCommerce namespace conventions
Add WordPress actions and filters with proper documentation including @since annotations
Implement dependency injection patterns using the WooCommerce container system
Write unit tests that extend WC_Unit_Test_Case with proper naming conventions
Apply WordPress Coding Standards including Yoda conditions and snake_case naming
Add PHPStan type annotations for static analysis including @template generics
limitations: Does not execute code or run tests - only provides guidelines for writing code
Does not modify files directly - guides AI agents in producing standards-compliant code
Focused on backend PHP code only - does not cover frontend JavaScript or React development
Does not provide WooCommerce API functionality - only development conventions

use_cases.title: Create WooCommerce extensions
use_cases.description: Build custom plugins that follow WooCommerce coding standards and integrate seamlessly with the platform.

use_cases.title: Contribute to WooCommerce core
use_cases.description: Add new features to WooCommerce using proper class structures, hooks, and testing patterns.

use_cases.title: Write unit tests
use_cases.description: Create comprehensive test coverage for backend functionality using the established test framework.

prompt_templates.title: New PHP class
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new class in src/Internal/Utils that processes customer data. Use dependency injection for Logger. Add proper PHPDoc with @since annotation.

prompt_templates.title: WordPress hook
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a new action hook that fires after order completion. Include proper docblock with @param tags and @since version annotation.

prompt_templates.title: Unit test
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a unit test for the OrderProcessor class. Test successful processing and error handling cases. Extend WC_Unit_Test_Case.

prompt_templates.title: Data operation
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a delete method to the CustomerDataProcessor class. Include validation to prevent data loss, verify ownership, and check for race conditions.

output_examples.input: Create a new class that calculates shipping rates with dependency injection for the tax calculator.
output: Uses init() method with @internal annotation for dependency injection
Pure static methods for calculations marked as static
PHPDoc includes @since annotation based on version from class-woocommerce.php

best_practices: Always verify entity state and ownership before performing delete or modify operations to prevent data loss
Use the DI container singleton pattern consistently - avoid creating multiple instances of the same service
Run linting and tests after every change and before committing to ensure code quality
anti_patterns: Avoid adding standalone functions - always wrap functionality in class methods for testability
Do not use named arguments in call_user_func_array() - use positional arguments instead
Never skip validation before data operations - always verify inputs, ownership, and entity state

faq.question: What versions of PHP does WooCommerce support?
faq.answer: WooCommerce requires PHP 8.1 or higher for modern code in the src/ directory.

faq.question: Where do new classes belong in the project structure?
faq.answer: New classes go in src/Internal/ by default. Public classes go directly in src/. Avoid adding new code to includes/ unless necessary.

faq.question: How does this skill integrate with the WooCommerce DI container?
faq.description: The skill provides guidelines for using the container pattern with init() methods and wc_get_container()->get() for retrieving service instances.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides documentation and guidelines. It does not execute code, access files, or make network requests.

faq.question: Why are my PHPStan checks failing?
faq.answer: Ensure you use proper @phpstan-param annotations for generic types. The skill includes patterns for @template declarations that enable correct type inference.

faq.question: How does this compare to generic PHP coding skills?
faq.answer: This skill provides WooCommerce-specific conventions including WordPress coding standards, the WooCommerce DI container, and proper hook documentation patterns.
